title: Buttermilk Biscuits & Sausage Gravy
description: Flaky, tender buttermilk biscuits topped with a creamy, savory pork sausage gravy seasoned with black pepper and a touch of sage. Classic Southern breakfast comfort food made from scratch with straightforward techniques: cold fat biscuits and a pan gravy finished with milk and plenty of cracked pepper.

ingredients.display_name: vegetable shortening, cold (optional for flakier layers)
pork breakfast sausage (bulk, no casing preferred)
ingredients.notes: mild or spicy depending on preference

steps.text: Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F). Line a baking sheet with parchment and chill it briefly if possible.

Make biscuit dough: In a large bowl combine dry ingredients for biscuits (flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, sugar). Cut cold butter (and optional shortening) into the flour using a pastry cutter or fingertips until mixture resembles coarse crumbs with some pea-size pieces remaining.

Add cold buttermilk to the dry mixture and stir gently with a fork until dough just comes together; do not overmix. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and fold 3–4 times to bring it together into a cohesive mass.

Pat or roll dough to about 1-inch thickness. Use a 2.5-inch round cutter to stamp biscuits straight down without twisting, re-form scraps gently and repeat to make the specified number of biscuits for the serving size.

Place biscuits close together on prepared sheet for taller sides, or spaced for crisper edges. Brush tops with a little extra buttermilk if desired. Bake in preheated oven until golden and risen, about 12–15 minutes. Remove and keep warm.

While biscuits bake, prepare sausage gravy: Heat a large skillet over medium heat. Add the bulk pork sausage and break it up with a spatula. Cook until browned and no longer pink, about 6–8 minutes, rendering fat.

Keep 2–3 tablespoons of the rendered fat in the skillet (drain excess if very greasy). Sprinkle the measured flour for the gravy over the cooked sausage and stir continuously for 1–2 minutes to cook the raw flour taste and form a roux.
Gradually whisk in warmed milk in increments to avoid lumps, bringing mixture to a gentle simmer. Cook, stirring frequently, until the gravy thickens to coat the back of a spoon, about 4–6 minutes.
Season the gravy with salt, a generous amount of cracked black pepper, and optional chopped sage and a splash of hot sauce. Taste and adjust seasoning.
Split warm biscuits in half and spoon the sausage gravy over the bottoms, cover with tops or serve open-faced. Serve immediately.
